metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JavaScript Function bind()
Function Borrowing
With the bind() method, an object can borrow a method from another object.
content.html: With the bind() method, an object can borrow a method from another object.

content.text: The example below creates 2 objects (person and member).
content.html: The example below creates 2 objects (person and member).

content.text: The member object borrows the fullname method from the person object:
content.html: The member object borrows the fullname method from the person object:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName:"John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  fullName: function () {
    return this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
  }
}

const member = {
  firstName:"Hege",
  lastName: "Nilsen",
}

let fullName = person.fullName.bind(member);

content.text: Preserving this
Sometimes the bind() method has to be used to prevent losing this .
content.html: Sometimes the bind() method has to be used to prevent losing this.

content.text: In the following example, the person object has a display method. In the display method, this refers to the person object:
content.html: In the following example, the person object has a display method. In the display method, this refers to the person object:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName:"John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  display: function () {
    let x = document.getElementById("demo");
    x.innerHTML = this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
  }
}

person.display();

content.text: When a function is used as a callback, this is lost.
content.html: When a function is used as a callback, this is lost.

content.text: This example will try to display the person name after 3 seconds, but it will display undefined instead:
content.html: This example will try to display the person name after 3 seconds, but it will display undefined instead:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName:"John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  display: function () {
    let x = document.getElementById("demo");
    x.innerHTML = this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
  }
}

setTimeout(person.display, 3000);

content.text: The bind() method solves this problem.
In the following example, the bind() method is used to bind person.display to person.
content.html: In the following example, the bind() method is used to bind person.display to person.

content.text: This example will display the person name after 3 seconds:
content.html: This example will display the person name after 3 seconds:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName:"John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  display: function () {
    let x = document.getElementById("demo");
    x.innerHTML = this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
  }
}

let display = person.display.bind(person);
setTimeout(display, 3000);

content.text: What is this ?
In JavaScript, the this keyword refers to an object .
content.html: In JavaScript, the this keyword refers to an object.

content.text: The this keyword refers to different objects depending on how it is used:
content.html: The this keyword refers to different objects depending on how it is used:

content.text: Note
this is not a variable. It is a keyword. You cannot change the value of this .
content.html: this is not a variable. It is a keyword. You cannot change the value of this.
